item.content:encoded:
Hello, world! I’ve recently taught myself how to set up this blog. It’s been quite a journey. I started by brushing off my rusty JavaScript skills (the last time I wrote anything in JavaScript was probably 2015), sat myself in a crash course on React.js, sat myself in another crash course in gatsby.js, and started working through templates.

I found this template here, which was developed by Alexander Shelepenok: Link to Repository. I came across it, as I was looking at Victor Zhou’s website on ML, and various projects (Victor Zhou’s Website). However, the template was far too complicated for my needs. It had several features that I don’t really need with this blog (yet). Those were things such as CMS compatibility, a docker deployment system, flow, jest (for testing, though I’ll eventually need that), and more.

So, I came across this much more simple template here, which I was able to navigate much easier: Link to Repository. It was developed by Kyle Matthews, the founder of Gatsby.js. It’s much more bare-bones, and I’m planning on using my knowledge of React.js and Gatsby.js to rework this site to be more than just a blog, but a showcase of the work I’ve done.

Of course, this will be a long ongoing project that I’m working on, but I hope this site will take it’s form soon.

Also, every blog post, I’m thinking of featuring one of the many film photos I took during my time in the Philippines, so here’s one for you now:

Until next time,

Keith Choa

item.content:encoded:
Here are some things I’ve learnt about how Gatsby.js dynamically generates content:

Regular Pages

Regular pages, that is, hard-coded pages (such as index.html and 404.html) are stored in src/pages/. Gatsby recognizes this, and these are compiled when gatsby deploy is run.

Blog Pages

Blog pages are not created individually. A template exists in src/templates/blog-post.js and the functions (made using a Node API) written in gatsby-node.js create the pages dynamically by using a GraphQL query to query the blog posts from /content/blog.

Note: “Node” is the name associated with all data added to Gatsby. I’m actually not too sure how this works. inside gatsby-node.js, there exists an exports.onCreateNode() function, which I don’t fully understand. I tried looking into the documentation, but couldn’t find much on it.

How does the template work?

The template takes in three sources of data:

  • data
    an object that contains query data within src/templates/blog-post.js. This is passed in when GraphQL is run within the same javascript file.
  • pageContext
    an object that contains data passed from gatsby-node.js This is passed as the context object in creatContext() inside of gatsby-node.js.
